Chapter on the Nature of the TathÄgata, Part 4, Section 2
At that time, Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, have a secret treasury.
This meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, only have secret words, not a secret treasury.
It is like a magician, a mechanical wooden person, although people see it bending, stretching, bowing, and looking up, they do not know what is inside that makes it so.
The Buddha's teachings are not like this, they make all sentient beings know and see, how can it be said that the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, have a secret treasury?
The Buddha praised KÄÅ›yapa, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
As you say, the TathÄgata truly has no secret treasury.
Why is it so?
It is like the full moon in autumn, appearing in the sky, clear and pure, without obstruction, seen by all people.
The words of the TathÄgata are also like this, revealing and manifesting, pure and unobstructed.
Foolish people do not understand and call it the secret treasury, but the wise who comprehend it do not call it a treasury.
Good man!

It is like a person who accumulates immeasurable billions of gold, silver, and other treasures, but is stingy and unwilling to give in charity to relieve the poor. Such accumulation is called a secret treasury.

The TathÄgata is not like this. For boundless eons, he has accumulated immeasurable precious Dharma treasures, and his mind is never stingy. He always gives them in charity to all sentient beings. How can one say that the TathÄgata has a secret treasury?
Good man!
It is like a person whose faculties are incomplete, who may lack one eye, one hand, or one foot. Out of shame, they do not let others see. Because others do not see, it is called a secret treasury.
The TathÄgata is not like this. His true Dharma is complete and without deficiency. He allows people to see it. How can it be said that the TathÄgata has a secret treasury?
Good man!
It is like a poor person who owes much to others. Fearing the creditors, he hides and does not want to show himself. Therefore, it is called a treasury.
The TathÄgata is not like this. He does not owe the worldly dharmas of all sentient beings. Although he owes the supramundane dharmas of sentient beings, he does not conceal them.
Why is this?
Because he always thinks of sentient beings as his only child and expounds the unsurpassed Dharma for them.
Good man!
It is like an elder who has much wealth and treasure, but only has one child. He loves him very much and never leaves his side. He uses all his precious treasures to show him.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He regards all sentient beings as his only child.
Good man!
It is like worldly people who cover their male and female organs with clothing because they are ugly and contemptible. Therefore, it is called a treasury.
The TathÄgata is not like this. He has forever severed this root. Because he has no root, there is nothing to conceal.
Good man!
It is like the treatises of the brahmins, which they never want the ká¹£atriyas, vaiÅ›yas, or Å›Å«dras to hear.
Why is this?
Because there are faults and evils in those treatises.
The true Dharma of the TathÄgata is not like this. It is good in the beginning, middle, and end. Therefore, it cannot be called a secret treasury.
Good man!

It is like an elder who has only one son. He always thinks of him, cherishes him, and never tires of loving him. He takes him to a teacher's place, wanting him to study. Fearing he will not quickly succeed, he takes him home again.
Because of his love, day and night he earnestly teaches him the half-letters, but does not teach him the vyÄkaraá¹‡a treatises.
Why is this?
Because he is still young and his strength is not yet sufficient.
Good man!
If the elder had taught the half-syllable, would the child then be able to understand the Pi-chia-lo treatise?
No, World-Honored One.
Thus, elder, would there be a secret treasury in that child?
No, World-Honored One.
Why is it so?
Because the child is young, it is not taught;
It is not because of secrecy that it is not taught.
Why is it so?
If there is a jealous and stingy mind, it is called a treasury.
The TathÄgata is not like this, so how can it be said that the TathÄgata has a secret treasury?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
As you have said.
If there is an angry mind, jealousy, and stinginess, it is called a treasury;
The TathÄgata has no angry mind and jealousy, so how can it be called a treasury?
Good man!
The great elder refers to the TathÄgata, and the only child refers to all sentient beings.

The TathÄgata regards all sentient beings as his only child. Teaching the only child refers to the Å›rÄvaka disciples, and the half-syllable refers to the nine divisions of the canon. The Pi-chia-lo treatise refers to the MahÄyÄna scriptures of the Vaipulya.

Because the Å›rÄvakas lack the power of wisdom, the TathÄgata teaches them the nine divisions of the canon with half-syllables, but does not teach them the Pi-chia-la treatise or the MahÄyÄna of the Vaipulya.
Good man!
If the elder's child has grown up and is able to study, but he does not teach him the Pi-chia-la treatise, it can be called a treasure.
If the Å›rÄvakas have the ability to accept the MahÄyÄna Pi-chia-la treatise, and the TathÄgata jealously does not teach it to them, it can be said that the TathÄgata has a secret treasury.
The TathÄgata is not like this, therefore the TathÄgata has no secret treasury.
Just as the elder, after teaching the half-syllable, next expounds the VyÄkaraá¹‡a;

I am now also like this. For the disciples, after explaining the nine-part sÅ«tras that are like the half-syllable, I next explain the VyÄkaraá¹‡a, which is that the TathÄgata eternally abides without change.
Moreover, good man!
It is like in the summer months, when great clouds and thunder arise, and heavy rain pours down, causing farmers who have planted seeds to reap abundant harvests.
Those who have not planted seeds will get nothing. Those who get nothing are not at fault with the dragon king.
And this dragon king also has nothing hidden.

I, the TathÄgata, am also like this. I pour down the great Dharma rain of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra. If sentient beings plant the seeds of goodness, they will obtain the fruits of the sprouts of wisdom.
Those without the seeds of goodness will get nothing.
Those who get nothing are not at fault with the TathÄgata;
Yet the Buddha, the TathÄgata, truly has nothing hidden.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
I now definitely know that the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, has nothing to conceal.
As the Buddha said in the Pischeli Sutra, 'The Buddha TathÄgata is eternally abiding and unchanging,' this meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
The Buddha once spoke a verse:
'The Buddhas, Pratyekabuddhas, and the assembly of disciples,
Still abandon their impermanent bodies, let alone ordinary people.'
Now he says:
'Eternally abiding and unchanging.'
What is the meaning of this?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
I taught this verse to all my ÅšrÄvaka disciples to teach the half-syllable.
Good man!
When King Prasenajit's mother passed away, he grieved and lamented, unable to control himself. He came to where I was. I then asked him:
'Great King!
Why are you so sorrowful and distressed to this extent?' The king said:
'World-Honored One!

The queen, the great consort, passed away on this day. If there is anyone who can restore my mother's life to what it was before, I will give up the country, elephants, horses, the seven treasures, and even my life to reward them.
' I further said:
'Great King!
Do not be sorrowful, worried, sad, or cry. The life of all beings ends, and that is called death.
Even the Buddhas, Pratyekabuddhas, and disciples of the Sravakas still abandon this body, let alone ordinary people?'
Good man!
I taught the half-syllable for King Prasenajit, and therefore spoke this verse.
I now teach the disciples of the Sravakas the Vyakarana, which states that the Tathagata is eternally present and unchanging.
If there is someone who says the Tathagata is impermanent, how is it that this person's tongue does not fall off?
Kasyapa said again:
As the Buddha has said:
'Do not hoard, be content with food.'
Like a bird flying through the sky, its tracks cannot be traced.
What is the meaning of this?
World-Honored One!
Who among this assembly is said to have nothing stored up?
Who is also said to be content with food?
Who walks in the empty traces that cannot be traced?
And where does the one who leaves go to?
The Buddha said:
Kasyapa!
What is called stored up refers to wealth and treasures.
Good man!
There are two kinds of stored up:
One is conditioned, the other is unconditioned.
The conditioned stored up refers to the practice of the Å›rÄvakas, while the unconditioned stored up refers to the practice of the TathÄgata.
Good man!
The Saá¹…gha is also of two kinds:
Conditioned and unconditioned.

The conditioned Saá¹…gha refers to the Å›rÄvakas, and the Å›rÄvaka Saá¹…gha has nothing stored up, namely slaves and other improper things, storehouses, grains, salt, fermented beans, and various large and small beans.
If there are those who say that the TathÄgata permits the keeping of slaves, servants, and such things, their tongues will curl up.
My disciples are called those who do not accumulate, and they are also called those who know contentment in food.
Those who greedily crave food are called those who do not know contentment.
Those who do not greedily crave food are called those who know contentment.
Those whose tracks are difficult to trace are close to the path of unsurpassed enlightenment. I say that such people, although they go, have no destination.

KÄÅ›yapa said again:ğŸ”½If even the saá¹ƒgha of the conditioned has no accumulation, how much less so the saá¹ƒgha of the unconditioned?ğŸ”½The saá¹ƒgha of the unconditioned is precisely the TathÄgata. How could the TathÄgata have any accumulation?
Accumulation is called hoarding. Therefore, the TathÄgata is not stingy or parsimonious in his teachings. How can he be called one who hoards?

The traces that cannot be sought refer to nirvana. In nirvana, there are no sun, moon, stars, constellations, cold, heat, wind, rain, birth, old age, sickness, death, or the twenty-five existences. It is free from all worries, sufferings, and afflictions. Such nirvana is the abode of the TathÄgata, eternally unchanging. For this reason, the TathÄgata has come to the sÄla trees and will attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the great nirvana.
The Buddha told KÄÅ›yapa:
As for the word 'great,' its nature is vast.
It is like a person whose lifespan is immeasurable, called a great man.
If such a person can abide in the true Dharma, he is called the most excellent among men.
As I have said, are the eight kinds of great man's awareness possessed by one person
or by many people?
If one person possesses all eight, he is the most excellent.
As for the word 'nirvana,' it means having no wounds or sores.
Good man!
It is like a person who is shot by a poisoned arrow and suffers greatly;
Meeting a good doctor, the poisoned arrow is pulled out and wonderful medicine is applied, causing them to be free from suffering and to experience peace and happiness.
The doctor then travels to towns and villages, and wherever there are afflictions and sores, he goes there to treat various illnesses.
Good man!

The TathÄgata is also like this. Having attained perfect enlightenment, he becomes the great medicine king. Seeing the suffering beings in JambudvÄ«pa who, for immeasurable eons, have been struck by the poisoned arrows of desire, anger, and delusion, and are experiencing great pain and distress,

For their sake, he expounds the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, the nectar-like Dharma medicine. Having treated them, he goes to other places where there are the poisoned arrows of afflictions, manifests as a buddha, and treats them. For this reason, it is called the great parinirvÄá¹‡a.

The great parinirvÄá¹‡a is called the place of liberation. Wherever there are beings to be tamed, the TathÄgata manifests himself there. Because of this true and profound meaning, it is called the great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Can all the physicians in the world cure all the wounds and illnesses of sentient beings?
Good man!
There are generally two kinds of wounds in the world:
One is curable, and the other is incurable.
Those that can be cured, the doctor can treat.
Those that cannot be cured, he cannot treat.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
According to what the Buddha says, the TathÄgata has already treated the sentient beings in JambudvÄ«pa.
If it is said that he has already treated them, then why are there still sentient beings among them who have not attained nirvÄá¹‡a?
If not all have attained it, why did the TathÄgata say that he has finished treating them and wants to go to other places?
Good man!
There are two kinds of beings in Jambudvipa:
Those with faith and those without faith.
Those with faith are called curable.
Why is this?
Because they will definitely attain nirvana, which is without sores or warts. Therefore, I say that I have cured all beings in Jambudvipa.
Those without faith are called icchantikas, and icchantikas are called incurable.
Excluding icchantikas, the rest have all been cured. Therefore, nirvana is called without sores or warts.
World-Honored One, what is called nirvana?
Good man!
Nirvana is called liberation.
Kasyapa said again:
What is called liberation, is it form or not form?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
It may be form or it may not be form.
The non-form is the liberation of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
The form is the liberation of the buddhas and tathÄgatas.
Good man!
Therefore, liberation is both form and non-form.
The TathÄgata teaches the disciples that it is non-form.
World-Honored One!
If the liberation of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is not form, how can it abide?
Good man!
Just as the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception is both form and non-form, I also say it is non-form.
If someone argues:
'If the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception is not form, how can it abide, come and go, move and stop?'
Such a meaning is the realm of the buddhas, not something known by the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.

Liberation is also like this. It is said to be non-form because it is both form and non-form. It is said to be non-thought because it is both thought and non-thought. Such meanings are the realm of the Buddhas, not known by the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
At that time, Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
I only pray that out of compassion, you will extensively explain the meaning of liberation, the practice of the great nirvÄá¹‡a.
The Buddha praised KÄÅ›yapa, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
True liberation is called the complete separation from all bonds.
If true liberation is free from all bonds, then it is unborn and also not a combination.
For example, a child is born from the combination of parents. True liberation is not like this. Therefore, liberation is called unborn.
KÄÅ›yapa!
For example, ghee is by nature pure.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He is not born from the combination of parents. His nature is pure.
Therefore, although he manifests having parents, it is in order to transform and liberate sentient beings.
True liberation is precisely the TathÄgata. The liberation of the TathÄgata is non-dual and without distinction.
It is like the seeds sown in spring. When they receive warmth, they immediately sprout.
True liberation is not like this.
Moreover, liberation is called emptiness. Emptiness is precisely liberation. Liberation is precisely the TathÄgata. The TathÄgata is precisely emptiness. He is not a creator or what is created.
All creators are like cities, palaces, towers, and ramparts;ğŸ”½true liberation is not like this. Therefore, liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.

Moreover, liberation is precisely the unconditioned dharma. It is like a potter who makes and then breaks. Liberation is not like this. True liberation is neither born nor extinguished. Therefore, liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.

The TathÄgata is also like this, not born, not extinguished, not aging, not dying, not broken, not destroyed, not a conditioned dharma. For this reason, it is called the TathÄgata entering great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
What is the meaning of not aging and not dying?
Aging is called change, with white hair and wrinkled face;
Death is the end of the body's life.
Such dharmas do not exist in liberation;
Because they are absent, it is called liberation.
The TathÄgata also has no white hair, wrinkled face, or conditioned dharmas, therefore the TathÄgata has no aging;
Because there is no aging, there is no death.

Moreover, liberation is called being free from illness. The so-called illnesses are the four hundred and four illnesses and other external harms to the body. Because they are absent here, it is called liberation.

Being without illness is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata. The TathÄgata is without illness, therefore the Dharma body is also without illness. Such an absence of illness is the TathÄgata.
Death is called the dissolution of the body and the end of life;
where there is no death is the nectar, and the nectar is true liberation. True liberation is the TathÄgata.
The TathÄgata has accomplished such merits, how can it be said that the TathÄgata is impermanent?
If it is said to be impermanent, it is not so.
This vajra body, how can it be impermanent?
Therefore the TathÄgata is not called one whose life ends.
The TathÄgata is pure and without defilement. The body of the TathÄgata is not defiled by the womb, like a lotus flower that is pure by nature.
The liberation of the TathÄgata is also like this. Such liberation is the TathÄgata. Therefore the TathÄgata is pure and without defilement.
Moreover, liberation is that all the wounds and sores of defilements are forever gone without remainder. The TathÄgata is also like this, without any wounds and sores of defilements.
Moreover, liberation is without contention. For example, a hungry person sees others' food and drink and gives rise to thoughts of greed and theft. Liberation is not like this.
Moreover, liberation is called tranquil. Worldly people say that what is tranquil is MahÃªÅ›vara. Such words are false.
True tranquility is ultimate liberation, and ultimate liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called peace. A place with many thieves is not called peaceful, while a place of purity is called peaceful.
In liberation there is no fear, so it is called peace. Therefore, peace is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata. The TathÄgata is the Dharma.
Moreover, liberation has no equal. That which has an equal has a neighboring country like a king.
Liberation is not like this. That which has no equal is like a wheel-turning sage king, who has no one who can match him.

Liberation is also like this, having no equal. That which has no equal is true liberation. True liberation is the TathÄgata, the wheel-turning king. Therefore, the TathÄgata has no equal. That which has an equal is impossible.
Moreover, liberation is called being without sorrow. That which has sorrow is like a king who fears a powerful neighbor and gives rise to sorrow.
Liberation is not like this. It is like destroying an enemy, then having no worries. Liberation is also like this, being without sorrow or fear. That which is without sorrow or fear is the TathÄgata.

Moreover, liberation is called being free from sorrow and joy. For example, a woman has only one child who goes far away on a journey. Suddenly she hears the news of his death and is filled with sorrow. Later she hears that he is alive and gives rise to joy.
In liberation there is no such thing. Being free from sorrow and joy is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is free from defilements. For example, in the spring, after the sun sets, the wind stirs up dust and mist.
In liberation there is no such thing. Being free from dust and mist is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
It is like the bright pearl in the topknot of a sage king, which is free from impurities.
The nature of liberation is also like this, free from impurities. Being free from impurities is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Just as the nature of true gold, unmixed with sand and stones, is called a true treasure. If a person obtains it, they will have the notion of wealth.
The nature of liberation is also like this. It is like that true treasure. That true treasure is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
It is just like a pottery jar, which when broken makes a cracking sound. A vajra treasure jar is not like this.
Liberation is also without cracking or breaking. A vajra treasure jar is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata. Therefore, the TathÄgata's body is indestructible.
That cracking sound is like a jujube seed. When it is very hot, if placed in the sun, it will make a loud popping sound.

Liberation is not like this. It is like a diamond treasure vase, without the sound of cracks. Even if countless hundreds of thousands of people were to shoot at it together, none would be able to destroy it, and there would be no sound of cracks. The sound of cracks is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
It is like a poor person who, because of owing others, is bound by them, with shackles, whips, and punishments, and suffers various hardships.
In liberation, there is no such thing. There is no debt. It is like an elder who has many treasures worth billions, with power and freedom, and does not owe others anything.

Liberation is also like this. It has many immeasurable treasures of the Dharma, with power and freedom, and nothing owed. Nothing owed is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called without oppression. It is like the heat of spring, the sweetness of summer food, and the cold touch of winter.
In true liberation, there are no such unpleasant things. Being without oppression is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Moreover, being without oppression is like a person who has eaten fish and meat and then drinks milk. Such a person will die soon.
In true liberation, there are no such things. If such a person obtains sweet dew and good medicine, their illness will be cured.
True liberation is also like this. Sweet dew and good medicine are metaphors for true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
What is meant by oppression and non-oppression?
It is like an ordinary person who, out of self-importance, thinks:
'Among all beings, who can harm me?'
And then they handle snakes, tigers, and poisonous insects. Know that such a person will not live out their lifespan and will die an unnatural death.
In true liberation, there are no such things.

Not oppressive is like a wheel-turning king, whose divine pearl can subdue all kinds of poisonous insects such as the dung beetle. If any hear the fragrance of this divine pearl, all poisons will be eliminated.
True liberation is also like this, completely free from the twenty-five existences. The elimination of poisons is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, not oppressive is like empty space. Liberation is also like this. That empty space is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, oppression is like dry grass near a burning lamp, which will blaze up if approached.
There is no such thing in true liberation.
Moreover, not oppressive is like the sun and moon, which do not oppress sentient beings.
Liberation is also like this, not oppressing sentient beings. Not oppressing is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called the unmoving dharma, like enemies and friends. In true liberation, there are no such things.
Moreover, the unmoving is like a wheel-turning king who has no other sage king as a close friend. If there were another close friend, it would not be so.

Liberation is also like this, having no close relatives. If there were close relatives, it would not be so. The king having no close relatives is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata. The TathÄgata is precisely the Dharma.
Moreover, the unmoving is like a white cloth that easily accepts the dyeing of colors. Liberation is not like this.
Moreover, the unmoving is like a pÄÅ›Ä« flower, wanting it to have a foul smell and blue color is not possible.
Liberation is also like this, wanting it to have a foul smell and various colors is also not possible. Therefore, liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called rare, just like a lotus flower growing in water is not rare, but one growing in fire is rare, and people seeing it would be delighted.
True liberation is also like this, those who see it will be delighted.
That which is rare is a metaphor for true liberation, true liberation is the TathÄgata, and the TathÄgata is the Dharma body.
Moreover, what is rare is like an infant whose teeth have not yet grown, gradually growing up and then they grow;
liberation is not like this, there is no growing or not growing.
Moreover, liberation is called empty and tranquil, without being indeterminate.
Being indeterminate is like a icchantika who is ultimately unmoved, one who commits grave offenses does not attain Buddhahood, this is impossible.
Why is it so?

If such a person gains pure faith in the Buddha's true Dharma, at that time they will have extinguished the icchantika. If they further become an upÄsaka, they will also be able to eliminate the icchantika. One who violates the grave precepts, after extinguishing this offense, will then be able to attain Buddhahood.
Therefore, if one says that they will definitely not attain Buddhahood without changing, this is not the case.
In true liberation, there is none of this extinguishing.
Moreover, emptiness and quiescence fall into the Dharma realm, and the nature of the Dharma realm is precisely true liberation. True liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Moreover, if the icchantika is completely extinguished, then they cannot be called an icchantika.
What is called an icchantika?
An icchantika is one who severs all wholesome roots, whose mind does not cling to any wholesome dharmas, and who does not even give rise to a single thought of goodness.
In true liberation, there are none of these things. Because there are none of these things, it is true liberation. True liberation is precisely the Tathagata.
Moreover, liberation is called immeasurable. It is like a grain heap whose quantity can be known.

True liberation is not like this. It is like the great ocean, which cannot be measured. Liberation is also like this, being immeasurable. The immeasurable is true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the Tathagata.
Moreover, liberation is called the Dharma of immeasurability. It is like a single sentient being having many karmic retributions.
Liberation is also like this, having immeasurable retributions. The immeasurable retributions are true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the Tathagata.
Moreover, liberation is called vast. It is like the great ocean, which is unmatched.
Liberation is also like this, being unmatched. The unmatched is true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the Tathagata.
Furthermore, liberation is called supreme, just like space, which is the highest and incomparable.
Liberation is also like this, being the highest and incomparable. The highest and incomparable is true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Furthermore, liberation is called unassailable, just like a place where a lion dwells, which cannot be passed by any of the hundred beasts.
Liberation is also like this, being unassailable. The unassailable is true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Furthermore, liberation is called unsurpassed, just like the north, which is the highest among the directions.
Liberation is also like this, being unsurpassed. The unsurpassed is true liberation, and true liberation is precisely the TathÄgata.
Furthermore, liberation is called the highest of the unsurpassed, just like the north to the east is the highest of the unsurpassed.
Liberation is also like this, without higher and higher. The absence of higher and higher is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called constant. For example, when the bodies of humans and gods disintegrate and life ends, this is called constant, not inconstant.
Liberation is also like this, not inconstant. Not inconstant is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called solid. For example, the nature of kÄdambaka sandalwood and agarwood is solid.
Liberation is also like this, with a solid nature. A solid nature is true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
Moreover, liberation is called not empty. For example, bamboo and reeds are hollow by nature;
liberation is not like this. One should know that liberation is the TathÄgata.

Furthermore, liberation is called undefiled. It is like a wall that has not yet been plastered. Mosquitoes and flies rest and play on it. If it is plastered and painted with colorful decorations, the insects smell the paint and do not stay.
Not staying like this is a metaphor for true liberation, and true liberation is the TathÄgata.
